QAPair.Question: What is (are) Plummer-Vinson syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: Plummer-Vinson syndrome is a condition that can occur in people with long-term (chronic) iron deficiency anemia . People with this condition have problems swallowing due to small, thin growths of tissue that partially block the upper food pipe (esophagus).

QAPair.Question: What causes Plummer-Vinson syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: The cause of Plummer-Vinson syndrome is unknown. Genetic factors and a lack of certain nutrients (nutritional deficiencies) may play a role. It is a rare disorder that can be linked to cancers of the esophagus and throat. It is more common in women.

QAPair.Question: What are the symptoms of Plummer-Vinson syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: Symptoms may include: Difficulty swallowing, Weakness ,

QAPair.Question: How to diagnose Plummer-Vinson syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: Your health care provider will do an exam to look for abnormal areas on your skin and nails. You may have an upper GI series or upper endoscopy to look for abnormal tissue in the food pipe. You may have tests to look for anemia or iron deficiency.

QAPair.Question: What are the treatments for Plummer-Vinson syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: Taking iron supplements may improve the swallowing problems. If supplements do not help, the web of tissue can be widened during upper endoscopy. This will allow you to swallow food normally.

QAPair.Question: What is the outlook for Plummer-Vinson syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: People with this condition generally respond to treatment.

QAPair.Question: What are the complications of Plummer-Vinson syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: Devices used to stretch the esophagus (dilators) may cause a tear. This can lead to bleeding. Plummer-Vinson syndrome has been linked to esophageal cancer .

QAPair.Question: Do I need to see a doctor for Plummer-Vinson syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: Contact your provider if: Food gets stuck after you swallow it, You have severe fatigue and weakness,

QAPair.Question: How to prevent Plummer-Vinson syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: Getting enough iron in your diet may prevent this disorder.
